Package edu.calpoly.spritely

Class SpriteWindow

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.calpoly.spritely.SpriteWindow

  • public class SpriteWindow
extends java.lang.Object
    A SpriteWindow is a frame for displaying a grid of equal-sized tiles in an animation. This is the main entry point for the Spritely framework.

    Tiles may overlap, that is, each position on the grid may have overlapping tiles. Each tile has both a graphical representation and a text representation; in text mode, only the topmost tile can be seen. Programs may contain multiple SpriteWindow instances.

    The basic lifecycle of a SpriteWindow application is as follows: 

        SpriteWindow window = new SpriteWindow();
    window.setXXX() (frames/second, callbacks, etc.)
    window.start();
    while (!window.getStopped()) {
        update any needed data structures
        AnimationFrame frame = window.waitForNextFrame();        
        call frame.addTile(x, y, Tile) for the displayed tiles;
        window.showNextFrame();
        do anything else you want to do
        if (you're done with window) {
            window.stop();
        }
    }
    System.exit(0);
    You are not required to have a single "event loop" like this, however. You can call frame.waitForNextFrame() and frame.showFrame() whenever you want to. It will only call your callbacks during a call to showNextFrame(), so you don't need to handle multi-threading.

    It's expected that you won't have multiple frames, but you can. This would be questionable in text mode, though. In graphics mode, if you want multiple frames, you can run each frame from its own thread, or you can arrange to call showNextFrame on the multiple frame objects, one after the other, from the same thread.

    • Constructor Detail

      • SpriteWindow

        public SpriteWindow​(java.lang.String name,
                    Size gridSize)
        Initialize a SpriteWindow to represent a grid gridSize.width columns wide and gridSize.height rows high.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of this window. This might be shown in the title area of the screen.
        gridSize - The number of rows and columns of the grid that is to be animated.
        See Also:
        setFps(double), setTileSize(Size), setKeyTypedHandler(KeyTypedHandler), setMouseClickedHandler(MouseClickedHandler)

    • Method Detail

      • setTextMode

        public static void setTextMode​()
        Forces the program into text mode. This is done by setting the Java system propery java.awt.headless to true. Normally, this isn't necessary -- if you're in an environment where graphics don't work, Java's graphics environment will detect that. This method can be useful for testing text mode when you're in an environment that supports graphics. It must be called before any operation that initializes the Java graphics subsystem.

      • setFps

        public void setFps​(double fps)
        Sets the number of frames/second that are displayed.
        Parameters:
        fps - The desired number of frames per second
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if start() has been called.
        See Also:
        DEFAULT_FPS

      • setTileSize

        public void setTileSize​(Size tileSize)
        Sets the tile size to the desired value.
        Parameters:
        tileSize - The desired tile size
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if start() has been called.
        See Also:
        DEFAULT_TILE_SIZE

      • getTileSize

        public Size getTileSize​()
        Get the size of the tiles this window is showing.
        Returns:
        The tile size, in pixels

      • setSilent

        public void setSilent​(boolean silent)
        Sets a flag to silence warnings that are sent to the terminal, such as when animation falls behind. This flag defaults to false. The flag can be changed at any time.
        Parameters:
        silent - true if you don't want to get warnings.

      • setKeyTypedHandler

        public void setKeyTypedHandler​(KeyTypedHandler handler)
        Sets a key typed handler. If a key is typed, the key typed event will be be sent to the handler during a call to waitForNextFrame()
        Parameters:
        handler - The handler.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if start() has been called, or if a handler was previously set.
        See Also:
        waitForNextFrame()

      • setMouseClickedHandler

        public void setMouseClickedHandler​(MouseClickedHandler handler)
        Sets a mouse handler. If the mouse is clicked, the mouse event will be sent to the handler during a call to waitForNextFrame()
        Parameters:
        handler - The handler.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if start() has been called.
        See Also:
        waitForNextFrame()

      • isRunning

        public boolean isRunning​()
        Returns true if this animation window is running . An animation window can be stopped by calling stop(). Additionally, it is stopped if the current thread is interrupted during a call to waitForNextFrame().
        Returns:
        true iff we're running
        See Also:
        Thread.interrupt(), stop()

      • getInitialFrame

        public AnimationFrame getInitialFrame​()
        Get an AnimationFrame to set up the initial screen, before start() is called. This is entirely optional, but it might help to avoid a flashing effect when a window is created. The window's tile size must not be changed after this is called.
        Returns:
        The frame where client code can add tiles to be drawn
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if we've started, or this has been called before.

      • start

        public void start​()
        Start this SpriteWindow. If our environment is graphics-capable, this will create a window where the graphics are displayed. This may only be called once per SpriteWindow.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if we were already started

      • stop

        public void stop​()
        Stop this SpriteWindow's animation, and close the window, if it's visible.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if we were never started

      • getTimeSinceStart

        public double getTimeSinceStart​()
        Give the time since the start of the animation of the current animation frame, in milliseconds. This value can drift off of wall clock time, if the animation is too slow. This can also happen if the program is suspended for a time, e.g. for debugging. It is therefore recommended that all time-based events in an animation be based off the time value returned by this method, rather than e.g. System.currentTimeMillis().
        Returns:
        The total elapsed time, adjusted for pauses, in milliseconds.
        See Also:
        pauseAnimation(int), System.currentTimeMillis()

      • waitForNextFrame

        public AnimationFrame waitForNextFrame​()
        Wait for the next frame of animation. Returns null if this window is stopped. If the current thread is interrupted, the window will be stopped.
        Returns:
        The frame where client code can add tiles to be drawn
        See Also:
        AnimationFrame.addTile(int, int, Tile)

      • showNextFrame

        public void showNextFrame​()
        Show the next frame of animation. The AnimationFrame last returned by waitForNextFrame is displayed to the screen.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if waitForNextFrame() has not been called, or if started has not been called.
        See Also:
        waitForNextFrame()

      • pauseAnimation

        public void pauseAnimation​(int pauseMS)
        Pause the animation for the given time, and reset the animation clock. Pausing the program might be useful for debugging. This is particularly ture in text mode, since the screen's cursor is constantly being sent to the home position, which tends to scramble debut output.
        Parameters:
        pauseMS - The number of seconds to pause
